## Order Scatterplots I

Order the following graphs from (a) lowest to highest value of r and (b) weakest to strongest.

```{r RChoose1, echo=FALSE, fig.width=6, fig.height=1.65}
par(mar=c(0.2,0.2,2,0.2),mfcol=c(1,4),xaxt="n",yaxt="n")
set.seed(349)
r <- c(0.6,-0.9,-0.5,0.1)
for (i in 1:length(r)) {
  x <- rmvnorm(n=100,mean=c(0,0),sigma=matrix(c(1,r[i],r[i],1),ncol=2))
  y <- x[,2]; x <- x[,1]
  plot(y~x,xlab="",ylab="",pch=21,bg="gray70",xlim=c(-3,3),ylim=c(-3,3))
  mtext(LETTERS[i],line=0.4,col="darkred")
}
```

[See answer here](zRevExAns/BEDAQuant.html#order-scatterplots-i)

## Order Scatterplots II

```{r RChoose2, echo=FALSE, fig.width=6, fig.height=1.65}

}
```

## Guess r

Five of the scatterplots below correspond to the following correlation coefficients --- 0.9, -0.5, -0.9, 0.6, 0.00. Identify the scatterplot that each correlation corresponds to. Some scatterplots will not be used.

```{r RChoose3, echo=FALSE, fig.width=6, fig.height=3}
par(mar=c(0,0,0,0),mfrow=c(2,4),xaxt="n",yaxt="n")
set.seed(349)
r <- c(0.3,0.9,0.6,-0.5,-0.3,0.995,0,-0.9)
for (i in 1:length(r)) {
  x <- rmvnorm(n=100,mean=c(0,0),sigma=matrix(c(1,r[i],r[i],1),ncol=2))
  y <- x[,2]; x <- x[,1]
  plot(y~x,xlab="",ylab="",pch=21,bg="gray70",xlim=c(-3,3),ylim=c(-3,3))
  text(-2.7,2.7,LETTERS[i],cex=1.5,col="darkred")
}
```

[See answer here](zRevExAns/BEDAQuant.html#guess-r)

## Hemlock and Deer
<img src="zimgs/DeerHemlock.jpg" alt="Deer Browsing Hemlock" class="img-right">

Researchers in Northern Wisconsin wanted to explain the role of Whitetail Deer (*Odocoileus virginianus*) as a keystone herbivore (Waller and Alverson 1997). As a part of their analysis, they examined the relationship between the mean number of Eastern Hemlock (*Tsuga canadensis*) saplings on 14 x 21 m sections of a woodlot and a browsing index (a complicated measurement that gives the amount of food a deer has eaten in a given area). Use the data in the table below to answer the folowing questions.

```
mean no. hemlock saplings  0.95 2.89 2.97 3.94 4.74 5.10 6.64 7.13
browse index               0.31 0.35 0.49 0.50 0.61 0.63 0.86 0.90
```

1. Make a scatterplot of the mean number of hemlock saplings versus browsing index.
1. Compute the correlation coefficient.

[See answer here](zRevExAns/BEDAQuant.html#hemlock-and-deer)
